title: PLAZA / WORKING CLASS WOMAN
description: [Aim√©e.] A dialogue with a woman who has a job. And a husband. And kids.

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still search..."
dialogueTree.text: "Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still searching for a book, her eyes wandering over the colourful grid of softcovers.

links.title: You: ""Protect and serve, madam! I found..."
links.text: "Protect and serve, madam! I found your husband."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""God damn it, I already told you --..."
links.text: "God damn it, I already told you -- my husband isn't missing!" She crosses her arms.

links.title: You: ""But you said you didn't know where..."
links.text: "But you said you didn't know where he was."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""And I specifically added that I di..."
links.text: "And I specifically added that I didn't *need* to know where he was."

links.title: You: ""Well, I found him nevertheless. I'..."
links.text: "Well, I found him nevertheless. I'm Dick Mullen."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Very well, then. Where is he?" She..."
links.text: "Very well, then. Where is he?" She's getting impatient, her hands now picking on a random book cover.

links.title: You: ""There." (Point to the working clas..."
links.text: "There." (Point to the working class drunk down near the sea.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Excuse me?!" She blinks. "I don't..."
links.text: "Excuse me?!" She blinks. "I don't follow."

links.title: Empathy: "There's something else hiding in he..."
links.text: There's something else hiding in her voice though -- a trace of worry.

links.title: You: ""I found a working class drunk and..."
links.text: "I found a working class drunk and I thought he might be yours."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Right, 'cause working class women..."
links.text: "Right, 'cause working class women come with alcoholic husbands." She glances over your shoulder towards the drunk. "You know what?"

links.title: Rhetoric: "Remember, about that *what* -- neve..."
links.text: Remember, about that *what* -- never-ever say *what*.

links.title: You: ""What?""
links.text: "What?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""You were right. I do have an alcoh..."
links.text: "You were right. I do have an alcoholic husband. Although not that one."

links.title: Reaction Speed: "Hah! Blam! Knew it."
links.text: Hah! Blam! Knew it.

links.title: You: ""But you told me your husband's all..."
links.text: "But you told me your husband's all right."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I did and he is." She takes a step..."
links.text: "I did and he is." She takes a step back. "He's also an alcoholic."

links.title: You: ""But didn't you say your husband wa..."
links.text: "But didn't you say your husband was kind and helpful?"

links.title: You: ""So is he missing as well?""
links.text: "So is he missing as well?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, he's not. Or maybe he is, I do..."
links.text: "No, he's not. Or maybe he is, I don't know. He's probably in the park, or in Jamrock somewhere. Drinking with his *friends*." She looks away.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I haven't seen him for... Well, to..."
links.text: "I haven't seen him for... Well, to hell with him!" She has completely forgotten about her books, staring blank into the distance instead.

links.title: Empathy: "There. She's worried now."
links.text: There. She's worried now.

links.title: You: ""Kim, is it just me or do we have a..."
links.text: "Kim, is it just me or do we have a missing person's case here?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I wouldn't be so sure," he replies..."
links.text: "I wouldn't be so sure," he replies, before turning to face the working class woman.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Ma'am, just to be completely clear..."
links.text: "Ma'am, just to be completely clear -- do you want to report it to the police?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Report what? He's just out, drinki..."
links.text: "Report what? He's just out, drinking with his friends... I'm sure the police has better things to do than to chase down local goofballs."

links.title: You: ""Not at all! The RCM is ready to ch..."
links.text: "Not at all! The RCM is ready to chase down every goofball in town. We care about you!"

links.title: You: ""Honestly, I just think missing per..."
links.text: "Honestly, I just think missing persons cases are mysterious."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""They're not all they're cracked up..."
links.text: "They're not all they're cracked up to be, officer."

links.title: Logic: "He's right. Missing person cases mo..."
links.text: He's right. Missing person cases most often involve runaway teenagers or demented old people. The victims usually turn up by themselves after a day or two spent missing. There's not much searching to do.

links.title: You: ""Okay, I get it. They're kinda bori..."
links.text: "Okay, I get it. They're kinda boring, right? Because eventually everyone returns home on their own."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Or they don't -- and you'll never..."
links.text: "Or they don't -- and you'll never find them," he adds with a flash of teeth.

links.title: You: ""But isn't *that* mysterious?""
links.text: "But isn't *that* mysterious?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I'd say there's nothing mysterious..."
links.text: "I'd say there's nothing mysterious about incompleteness. It's in fact rather unpleasant."

links.title: Inland Empire: "You're wrong there. Incompleteness..."
links.text: You're wrong there. Incompleteness is the essence of mystery.

links.title: You: ""Well, I still want one. I want a m..."
links.text: "Well, I still want one. I want a missing person's case!"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""All right then..." He sighs. "He h..."
links.text: "All right then..." He sighs. "He has *questions* now."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What kind of questions?""
links.text: "What kind of questions?"

links.title: You: ""Okay, I don't want it. Let's move..."
links.text: "Okay, I don't want it. Let's move on." (Don't take the case.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Great, let's do it.""
links.text: "Great, let's do it."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "The working class woman doesn't say..."
links.text: The working class woman doesn't say anything, her eyes still fixed on something invisible in the distance. Some seagulls fly over her head.

links.title: You: ""Why not?""
links.text: "Why not?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Because people either show up on t..."
links.text: "Because people either show up on their own or you'll never find them," he says with a flash of teeth.

links.title: You: ""You're right, unfortunately our fo..."
links.text: "You're right, unfortunately our forces are limited. I'm sure he'll return on his own." (Don't take the case.)

links.title: You: ""Don't worry, I'm going to find him..."
links.text: "Don't worry, I'm going to find him and bring him back home, promise."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She sighs, but you can detect a sli..."
links.text: She sighs, but you can detect a slight hint of gratitude and relief from her face.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Alright, go ahead. Do you have any..."
links.text: "Alright, go ahead. Do you have any questions?"

links.title: You: ""Well, if he's with his *friends*,..."
links.text: "Well, if he's with his *friends*, then he's not really missing. No need for the police to get involved." (Don't take the case.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She just nods, still staring into t..."
links.text: She just nods, still staring into the distance. Some seagulls fly over her head.

links.title: You: ""I'm not saying 'what'.""
links.text: "I'm not saying 'what'."

links.title: You: ""Something bad I guess? I'm sorry,..."
links.text: "Something bad I guess? I'm sorry, I say stupid things sometimes, I didn't mean to annoy."

links.title: You: ""Right around the corner. He has pi..."
links.text: "Right around the corner. He has pissed himself."

links.title: You: ""Our hammer toting comrade was at t..."
links.text: "Our hammer toting comrade was at the bottom of those stairs."

links.title: You: ""Well, I found him nevertheless. I'..."
links.text: "Well, I found him nevertheless. I'm that good."

links.title: You: ""Let's talk about your husband agai..."
links.text: "Let's talk about your husband again."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Right. What about him?" Her face b..."
links.text: "Right. What about him?" Her face becomes anxious again.

links.title: You: ""What does your husband look like?""
links.text: "What does your husband look like?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Honestly, not that different from..."
links.text: "Honestly, not that different from you." She eyes you from head to toe.

links.title: You: ""So let me guess... he's *disco*?""
links.text: "So let me guess... he's *disco*?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Oh, thank god, no!" She nearly beg..."
links.text: "Oh, thank god, no!" She nearly begins to laugh. "It hasn't come down to *this* yet."

links.title: Half Light: "Hold on! Did she just laugh at your..."
links.text: Hold on! Did she just laugh at your disco pants? You're not going to leave it there, are you?

links.title: Rhetoric: "Technically speaking, your trousers..."
links.text: Technically speaking, your trousers could be considered part of your work gear. This means she has insulted *the police*.

links.title: Half Light: "Hold on! Did she just laugh at disc..."
links.text: Hold on! Did she just laugh at disco? You're not going to leave it there, are you?

links.title: You: ""Wow, ma'am! Do we have a *problem*..."
links.text: "Wow, ma'am! Do we have a *problem* here?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What problem?""
links.text: "What problem?"

links.title: You: ""Do we have a problem with *police*?""
links.text: "Do we have a problem with *police*?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Police? I don't follow." She narro..."
links.text: "Police? I don't follow." She narrows her eyes, trying to understand.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What does anything I said have to..."
links.text: "What does anything I said have to do with police? Or is *Police* some kind of disco phenomenon as well?"

links.title: You: ""Yes, I make disco become a police..."
links.text: "Yes, I make disco become a police thing -- and you have just insulted my style."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Oh, no! That's not what I meant!"..."
links.text: "Oh, no! That's not what I meant!" She takes a step back.

links.title: You: ""No. But I am an officer of the law..."
links.text: "No. But I am an officer of the law and you have just insulted my work uniform."

links.title: You: ""Do we have a problem with *disco*?""
links.text: "Do we have a problem with *disco*?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, no..." she backs off, "my rela..."
links.text: "No, no..." she backs off, "my relationship with disco remains irrefutably healthy."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What I was trying to say before is..."
links.text: "What I was trying to say before is that he's a little bit chubby, that's all. I didn't mean anything offensive!"

links.title: You: ""Why did you say that your husband..."
links.text: "Why did you say that your husband resembles me then?"

links.title: You: ""Like a late-stage alcoholic then.""
links.text: "Like a late-stage alcoholic then."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""That's one way to put it, yes. No..."
links.text: "That's one way to put it, yes. No offence. I'd also add that he's a little bit chubby."

links.title: Physical Instrument: "Wait! Did she just imply that you'r..."
links.text: Wait! Did she just imply that you're *fat*? You're not fat! The body type she's referring to is called a *Franconigerian hard-body*.

links.title: You: ""I'm not *chubby* and neither is yo..."
links.text: "I'm not *chubby* and neither is your husband. What you meant to say is that we both share a *Franconigerian hard-body*."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""You both share *what*?" She doesn'..."
links.text: "You both share *what*?" She doesn't understand.

links.title: You: ""*Franconigerian hard-body*. Softly..."
links.text: "*Franconigerian hard-body*. Softly round, yet still in shape. Ladies dig it."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I'm not sure about the rest, but s..."
links.text: "I'm not sure about the rest, but softly round sounds about right. He's not in great shape." She stops to think.

links.title: You: ""I see. What else?""
links.text: "I see. What else?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What else... He was wearing a dark..."
links.text: "What else... He was wearing a dark brown leather jacket with a bright blue inner lining. The lining is hand-sewn, I made it myself." She sighs, her voice slightly quivering when she adds:

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""It's his *cool jacket*. God knows..."
links.text: "It's his *cool jacket*. God knows it's too cold to run around in this, but he refuses to change."

links.title: Composure: "Who cares about the cold when you h..."
links.text: Who cares about the cold when you have your *cool jacket* to wear? You can completely sympathize.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I even tried throwing it away once..."
links.text: "I even tried throwing it away once, but he just dug it out of the bin. Can you believe it?" She looks back at you, shaking her head.

links.title: You: ""Well, if that jacket is really *th..."
links.text: "Well, if that jacket is really *that cool*, then I can totally understand..."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Well, what can you do... I hope th..."
links.text: "Well, what can you do... I hope that at least that extra lining helps him keep warm at night. I wouldn't like him to catch cold."

links.title: Empathy: "She's thinking about him out in the..."
links.text: She's thinking about him out in the cold -- in some park or on the coast -- and it's making her more and more worried.

links.title: You: ""He *took it out of the bin*? Wow...."
links.text: "He *took it out of the bin*? Wow. That's filthy."

links.title: You: ""Right -- we're dealing with a cop.""
links.text: "Right -- we're dealing with a cop."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, no!" Her eyes widen at your mi..."
links.text: "No, no!" Her eyes widen at your misunderstanding. "He is definitely not a cop. I meant that he's a little chubby, that's all."

links.title: You: ""What do you mean by that?""
links.text: "What do you mean by that?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Well, he's... slightly chubby.""
links.text: "Well, he's... slightly chubby."

links.title: You: ""When did you last see him?""
links.text: "When did you last see him?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Yesterday morning. He went to the..."
links.text: "Yesterday morning. He went to the library." Her eyes become cold with recollection. "He went to retrieve my book and he promised, he *promised* he'd walk straight back home."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Because we talked about this. We t..."
links.text: "Because we talked about this. We talked about not wandering off again!" She scoffs. "I don't know what to do! I honestly don't know what to do with his addiction... It just makes me feel weak."

links.title: Logic: "Gone for around 36 hours then? Damn..."
links.text: Gone for around 36 hours then? Damn, this *is* a missing persons case.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She turns away from you in an attem..."
links.text: She turns away from you in an attempt to recover.

links.title: You: ""I think I got it, thanks." (Procee..."
links.text: "I think I got it, thanks." (Proceed.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She gives you a short nod, before r..."
links.text: She gives you a short nod, before returning to her books.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""So you *are* going to look for him?""
links.text: "So you *are* going to look for him?"

links.title: Suggestion: "She genuinely wants you to, now. Do..."
links.text: She genuinely wants you to, now. Don't make her ask.

links.title: You: ""Yes, I will bring him back home to..."
links.text: "Yes, I will bring him back home to you." (Take the case.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Thank you!" You sense gratitude in..."
links.text: "Thank you!" You sense gratitude in her voice. "Please, do... Even though I'm sure he will return home by himself. I'm still sure of that."

links.title: Volition: "She tries to maintain a brave front..."
links.text: She tries to maintain a brave front, even though her eyes reveal the opposite.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I'm sure he will too. When he does..."
links.text: "I'm sure he will too. When he does, would you let Precinct 57 -- Kim Kitsuragi -- know." He gives her a slip of paper.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I will. Of course, officer. As I s..."
links.text: "I will. Of course, officer. As I said, it's probably nothing." The woman takes the slip of paper. It's a phone number.

links.title: You: ""Sorry, we've got our hands full at..."
links.text: "Sorry, we've got our hands full at the moment. Maybe some time later." (Don't take the case.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Yes. Right." A wave of despair swe..."
links.text: "Yes. Right." A wave of despair sweeps over her face. "He wasn't missing anyway," she tries to say while struggling to maintain a courageous front, "I'm sure he'll be home."

links.title: Empathy: "It is clear from her voice that she..."
links.text: It is clear from her voice that she is shattered.

links.title: You: ""You were right that I'm a cockatoo.""
links.text: "You were right that I'm a cockatoo."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Excuse me?""
links.text: "Excuse me?"

links.title: You: ""I went and read up on them, just l..."
links.text: "I went and read up on them, just like you said. And I even decided on what kind of a cockatoo I am. Want to know?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I don't know, the most talkative o..."
links.text: "I don't know, the most talkative one?" She's ready to put that question aside.

links.title: You: ""No, I'm the bang-bang cockatoo.""
links.text: "No, I'm the bang-bang cockatoo."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""The what now?!""
links.text: "The what now?!"

links.title: You: ""The bang-bang cockatoo. It's the m..."
links.text: "The bang-bang cockatoo. It's the most common one."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "The woman looks baffled by your per..."
links.text: The woman looks baffled by your personal revelation. "You truly are one *strange* cop, aren't you?" she says, slowly shaking her head.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "The wind brings a strand of hair to..."
links.text: The wind brings a strand of hair to her rough face. "I have a strange cop offering to find my stupid husband. What a day..."

links.title: You: ""The funeral cockatoo. It's the mos..."
links.text: "The funeral cockatoo. It's the most depressing one."

links.title: You: ""The Major Majestic cockatoo. It's..."
links.text: "The Major Majestic cockatoo. It's the most impressive one."

links.title: You: ""The fuckupatoo. It's the one who a..."
links.text: "The fuckupatoo. It's the one who always fucks everything up."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, you're not. Don't think that....."
links.text: "No, you're not. Don't think that..." she says, slowly shaking her head. The wind brings a strand of hair to her rough face. "You're the cockatoo who offered to find my stupid husband. Let's leave it at that."

links.title: Empathy: "She doesn't want you to be the fuck..."
links.text: She doesn't want you to be the fuckupatoo.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, you're not. Don't think that w..."
links.text: "No, you're not. Don't think that way..." she says, slowly shaking her head. The wind brings a strand of hair to her rough face. "You're just a regular talkative cockatoo and let's leave it at that, okay?"

links.title: You: ""No, I'm the funeral cockatoo.""
links.text: "No, I'm the funeral cockatoo."

links.title: You: ""No, I'm the Major Majestic cockato..."
links.text: "No, I'm the Major Majestic cockatoo."

links.title: You: ""No, I'm the fuckupatoo.""
links.text: "No, I'm the fuckupatoo."

links.title: You: ""Forget it. It's too personal.""
links.text: "Forget it. It's too personal."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Some things *are* officer." She no..."
links.text: "Some things *are* officer." She nods. Her cheeks are red from the cold.

links.title: You: ""Maybe your husband is missing?""
links.text: "Maybe your husband is missing?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""My husband? No, he's not.""
links.text: "My husband? No, he's not."

links.title: You: ""This little girl over there told m..."
links.text: "This little girl over there told me you have a bad husband."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Excuse me, a *bad husband?*" Her b..."
links.text: "Excuse me, a *bad husband?*" Her back straightens. "What do you mean?"

links.title: You: ""Not a nice and helpful sort.""
links.text: "Not a nice and helpful sort."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Do *police men* just go around rep..."
links.text: "Do *police men* just go around repeating what some kid off the street said?"

links.title: Empathy: "She doesn't mean to be antagonistic..."
links.text: She doesn't mean to be antagonistic, but she can't help coming off defensive.

links.title: You: ""Those were her words, not mine. I'..."
links.text: "Those were her words, not mine. I'm merely asking."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Can I give you some friendly advic..."
links.text: "Can I give you some friendly advice, mister policeman? Don't listen to kids."

links.title: You: ""So you don't have a bad husband?""
links.text: "So you don't have a bad husband?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, I don't. I have a good husband..."
links.text: "No, I don't. I have a good husband, the kind and helpful sort. And he's *not* missing."

links.title: Empathy: "He's totally missing."
links.text: He's totally missing.

links.title: You: ""She isn't just some 'kid off the s..."
links.text: "She isn't just some 'kid off the street'. She seems very mature for her age."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Is she now?" She dries her hands i..."
links.text: "Is she now?" She dries her hands in the apron underneath her coat. Her eyes narrow.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Annette's a sweet sprout, but she..."
links.text: "Annette's a sweet sprout, but she doesn't know anything about marriage. Why am I even talking about this..."

links.title: You: ""So where could he be?""
links.text: "So where could he be?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I don't know, at home now? Out dri..."
links.text: "I don't know, at home now? Out drinking with his friends? Working?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Where is this going, officer?""
links.text: "Where is this going, officer?"

links.title: You: ""So what I'm hearing is: you don't..."
links.text: "So what I'm hearing is: you don't really *know* where your husband is."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Yes, but..." She looks around and..."
links.text: "Yes, but..." She looks around and takes a deep breath, a little annoyed. "I don't really need to know where my husband is. Not all the time."

links.title: You: ""Wouldn't you like to?""
links.text: "Wouldn't you like to?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No." She looks you straight into t..."
links.text: "No." She looks you straight into the eye. Her right foot is tapping nervously.

links.title: You: ""I can totally help you find your m..."
links.text: "I can totally help you find your missing husband."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Why are we still talking about thi..."
links.text: "Why are we still talking about this? I haven't lost my husband."

links.title: Empathy: "She has though. The husband is tota..."
links.text: She has though. The husband is totally lost. You should tell her that it's okay.

links.title: You: ""Hush, baby.""
links.text: "Hush, baby."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What?""
links.text: "What?"

links.title: You: ""It's all right to not know where y..."
links.text: "It's all right to not know where your husband is. Nothing shameful in that."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Who said anything about shame? Sto..."
links.text: "Who said anything about shame? Stop talking down to me." She puts her foot down. "My husband is not missing."

links.title: Inland Empire: "But he *is*... you can feel it. Or..."
links.text: But he *is*... you can feel it. Or maybe it's something else then!

links.title: You: ""No, I was talking to myself. I sho..."
links.text: "No, I was talking to myself. I should stop. It's okay."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She tries to concentrate on books,..."
links.text: She tries to concentrate on books, but her eyes are full of bewilderment.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Okay! Maybe it's something else the..."
links.text: Okay! Maybe it's something else then.

links.title: You: ""It's okay.""
links.text: "It's okay."

links.title: You: "Let go."
links.text: Let go.

links.title: Logic: "It's gotta be something else then...."
links.text: It's gotta be something else then. Why else would you be asking her if it wasn't?

links.title: Physical Instrument: "Kids are always going missing. Weak..."
links.text: Kids are always going missing. Weak, pathetic kids. Always getting themselves killed.

links.title: You: ""Suit yourself then. I don't really..."
links.text: "Suit yourself then. I don't really care if your husband is missing."

links.title: You: ""Maybe you¬¥re right. Maybe he isn't..."
links.text: "Maybe you¬¥re right. Maybe he isn't missing indeed."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Of course he's not. It's not like..."
links.text: "Of course he's not. It's not like he's a pocket watch. I wouldn't just lose him."

links.title: You: ""Right, got it, thanks.""
links.text: "Right, got it, thanks."

links.title: You: ""Okay, thanks.""
links.text: "Okay, thanks."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Mhm. You're welcome." She reverts..."
links.text: "Mhm. You're welcome." She reverts her attention back to the book stand.

links.title: You: ""Maybe your children are missing?""
links.text: "Maybe your children are missing?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No. Absolutely not." Her words com..."
links.text: "No. Absolutely not." Her words come out quick as gunshots.

links.title: You: ""Okay. So where are they?""
links.text: "Okay. So where are they?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Are you a police man or a nanny?"..."
links.text: "Are you a police man or a nanny?" She's definitely disturbed by now.

links.title: You: ""Nanny. Where are they?""
links.text: "Nanny. Where are they?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""They're not missing, sir.""
links.text: "They're not missing, sir."

links.title: Electrochemistry: "You know where they are. They're at..."
links.text: You know where they are. They're at home. *Smoking*. Giving the ladder of vices a chance.

links.title: Inland Empire: "What if something horrible has happ..."
links.text: What if something horrible has happened? What if they're dead. That's the bad vibe you got before.

links.title: Savoir Faire: "No, they're at a disco. Getting dow..."
links.text: No, they're at a disco. Getting down. Stupid disco dancing teenagers.

links.title: You: ""They are at home, right? Smoking c..."
links.text: "They are at home, right? Smoking cigarettes."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What? That's just -- my daughters..."
links.text: "What? That's just -- my daughters are perfectly *fine*. They're with their friends down in Jamrock! There's *nothing* to worry about."

links.title: Empathy: "She's getting upset. Her voice has..."
links.text: She's getting upset. Her voice has risen, as she tries to convince herself that her daughters are safe.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""They're almost grown up now anyway..."
links.text: "They're almost grown up now anyway. They're past the age they need me protecting them from everything now."

links.title: Half Light: "What is this *doubt* you have then?..."
links.text: What is this *doubt* you have then? Something *has* happened here.

links.title: You: ""I'm afraid the danger is now great..."
links.text: "I'm afraid the danger is now greater than ever. Tell me, how old are they?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""My youngest girl, Jolie, is just s..."
links.text: "My youngest girl, Jolie, is just shy of sixteen. Jennie, she is turning eighteen next month. But we shouldn't even be talking about them!"

links.title: You: ""And can you describe me their appe..."
links.text: "And can you describe me their appearance? Any features that stand out, something to make identifying a little easier?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Why do you need to know this? Have..."
links.text: "Why do you need to know this? Haven't I repeatedly told you that they are not missing? That they're in Jamrock, safe and well, at some stupid party."

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Did someone say... party? You could..."
links.text: Did someone say... party? You could use a party. Hunt it down!

links.title: You: ""I could do with a party.. A *kille..."
links.text: "I could do with a party.. A *killer* party, not a lame-o one!"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""A 'killer' party? What is it with..."
links.text: "A 'killer' party? What is it with you and *pulp* staples? My god. Please, no more talk about my daughters. They are fine!" She picks up a book and tries to concentrate. A flock of seabirds passes by.

links.title: Logic: "Okay. It must be asked then -- what..."
links.text: Okay. It must be asked then -- what *are* you doing here? Why are you pursuing this? Is it a *hunch*?

links.title: You: ""It's for the investigation. I'm tr..."
links.text: "It's for the investigation. I'm trying to be professional."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""There is no *investigation* here,..."
links.text: "There is no *investigation* here, I can tell you that!" She picks up a book and tries to concentrate. A flock of seabirds passes by.

links.title: You: ""You're right, let's not talk about..."
links.text: "You're right, let's not talk about your daughters. I don't know what got into me."

links.title: You: ""Maybe you're right. Maybe they are..."
links.text: "Maybe you're right. Maybe they aren't missing after all. Tell me something else..."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmh?" She adjusts her scarf, cheek..."
links.text: "Hmh?" She adjusts her scarf, cheeks rough and ruddy from the wind.

links.title: You: ""I know where they are. At the disc..."
links.text: "I know where they are. At the disco, dancing nasty."

links.title: You: ""What if something awful has happen..."
links.text: "What if something awful has happened... what if they're in the sewers."

links.title: You: ""Okay, great. Just making sure.""
links.text: "Okay, great. Just making sure."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Mhm, I see. Thanks." She tries to..."
links.text: "Mhm, I see. Thanks." She tries to read again.

links.title: You: ""I police whatever I want. Where ar..."
links.text: "I police whatever I want. Where are they?"

links.title: You: ""Right, thanks.""
links.text: "Right, thanks."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She gives you a short nod and shift..."
links.text: She gives you a short nod and shifts her attention back to books.

links.title: You: ""Maybe your *cockatoo* is missing?""
links.text: "Maybe your *cockatoo* is missing?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I don't mean to disrespect, sir, b..."
links.text: "I don't mean to disrespect, sir, but *you* are being a bit of a cockatoo here."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""For what it's worth -- I agree. Bu..."
links.text: "For what it's worth -- I agree. But cockatoos can't be stopped when they get like this. It's better to indulge him at this point."

links.title: You: ""Ma'am, I was asking about your coc..."
links.text: "Ma'am, I was asking about your cockatoo. Is it missing?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I don't even have a cockatoo. And..."
links.text: "I don't even have a cockatoo. And guess what?"

links.title: Rhetoric: "It's a trap. Never ever say *what*."
links.text: It's a trap. Never ever say *what*.

links.title: You: ""What?""
links.text: "What?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Even if I had, it wouldn't be miss..."
links.text: "Even if I had, it wouldn't be missing."

links.title: You: ""Alright, cockatoo not missing. I j..."
links.text: "Alright, cockatoo not missing. I just wanted to make sure."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Great." She turns her attention ba..."
links.text: "Great." She turns her attention back to the bookstand.

links.title: You: ""Just one more question: what did y..."
links.text: "Just one more question: what did you mean by me being a cockatoo?"

links.title: You: ""Great. Got it.""
links.text: "Great. Got it."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Wonderful.""
links.text: "Wonderful."

links.title: You: ""What do you mean I'm being a cocka..."
links.text: "What do you mean I'm being a cockatoo?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Nothing. Go read up on them if you..."
links.text: "Nothing. Go read up on them if you're so interested. There's a great book in the bookstore."

links.title: Inland Empire: "Maybe you should check that cockato..."
links.text: Maybe you should check that cockatoo book again... What if the cockatoo is your *heraldic bird*?

links.title: You: ""Actually, that's exactly what I'm..."
links.text: "Actually, that's exactly what I'm going to do, thanks for the tip." (Get task.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Wonderful. The store is open.""
links.text: "Wonderful. The store is open."

links.title: You: ""You're being sarcastic. Let's talk..."
links.text: "You're being sarcastic. Let's talk about something else." (Move on.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Please, let's do.""
links.text: "Please, let's do."

links.title: Inland Empire: "Maybe you should... What if the coc..."
links.text: Maybe you should... What if the cockatoo is your *astral captain*? Or your *heraldic bird*?

links.title: You: "Watch her browse books."
links.text: Watch her browse books.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "Her hands move over the book covers..."
links.text: Her hands move over the book covers. The tips of her fingers look rough, stained with yellow. It seems like she has spent a lot of time at work, smoking.

links.title: Rhetoric: "Another comrade! Years of labour ar..."
links.text: Another comrade! Years of labour are pressing down on her shoulders. She deserves a hug -- for all the work she's done for mankind.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "An array of neurons fires up with j..."
links.text: An array of neurons fires up with joy. Bum her a cigarette -- lest it turn to pain.

links.title: You: ""Do you have any money?""
links.text: "Do you have any money?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Money?" She looks up to you, a con..."
links.text: "Money?" She looks up to you, a confused smile crossing her lips. "Does the working class ever have any money?"

links.title: Visual Calculus: "She starts coughing. It's definitel..."
links.text: She starts coughing. It's definitely a smoker's cough.

links.title: You: ""You're right, I should find myself..."
links.text: "You're right, I should find myself a *capitalist*!"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Mhmh. Exactly. Go ask for an inves..."
links.text: "Mhmh. Exactly. Go ask for an investment." Her words are clipped, but not unamused. Her eyes turn back to the book stand.

links.title: You: ""I wasn't thinking much, maybe like..."
links.text: "I wasn't thinking much, maybe like a few cents or so?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, sorry," she puts her hands int..."
links.text: "No, sorry," she puts her hands into her coat pockets, as if cold from wind. "I don't have anything to spare."

links.title: You: ""So your *money* is *missing*?""
links.text: "So your *money* is *missing*?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No! No-no-no. I'm not missing my m..."
links.text: "No! No-no-no. I'm not missing my money. End of story." She returns her attention back to the book stand.

links.title: You: ""Sad. I'll bum somebody else then.""
links.text: "Sad. I'll bum somebody else then."

links.title: You: ""Do you smoke?""
links.text: "Do you smoke?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, I don't.""
links.text: "No, I don't."

links.title: You: ""I know for a fact that you smoke.""
links.text: "I know for a fact that you smoke."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Why do you think that I smoke?" Sh..."
links.text: "Why do you think that I smoke?" She looks up, slightly startled.

links.title: You: ""That cough you had. It's a smoker'..."
links.text: "That cough you had. It's a smoker's cough."

links.title: Working Class Woman: "Her eyes shimmer over yours. "You'r..."
links.text: Her eyes shimmer over yours. "You're a keen observer," she remarks.

links.title: You: ""Just give me a cigarette please.""
links.text: "Just give me a cigarette please."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I already told you -- I don't have..."
links.text: "I already told you -- I don't have any. Go bother someone else."

links.title: Half Light: "She's lying. She's god damn lying,..."
links.text: She's lying. She's god damn lying, she has smokes!

links.title: You: ""Just one, I beg you. Just one. GIV..."
links.text: "Just one, I beg you. Just one. GIVE ME THE DAMN CIGARETTE, MA'AM!"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I can't give you what I don't have..."
links.text: "I can't give you what I don't have." She turns away from you, focusing on the books again.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant sighs."
links.text: The lieutenant sighs.

links.title: You: ""I *know* you're lying, please just..."
links.text: "I *know* you're lying, please just give me a cigarette."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, I'm not lying. Why should I li..."
links.text: "No, I'm not lying. Why should I lie?" A pause. "Please go to the Frittte kiosk."

links.title: Half Light: "You'd lie too, wouldn't you? You'd..."
links.text: You'd lie too, wouldn't you? You'd lie and steal and cheat! Ask her again, squeeze the truth out of her. Keep pressing. Ask, ask, *ask*!

links.title: You: ""Just gimme your cigarettes, okay?..."
links.text: "Just gimme your cigarettes, okay? Don't lie."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Sorry, officer?" She stares at you..."
links.text: "Sorry, officer?" She stares at you in disbelief.

links.title: Half Light: "SHE'S LYING, LYING, LYING!"
links.text: SHE'S LYING, LYING, LYING!

links.title: You: ""Do you know where I could get a ne..."
links.text: "Do you know where I could get a new pack?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""From the kiosk? There's one near t..."
links.text: "From the kiosk? There's one near the harbour, it's a Frittte. You can look it up."

links.title: You: ""Okay, thanks, no problem." (Move o..."
links.text: "Okay, thanks, no problem." (Move on.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She sighs."
links.text: She sighs.

links.title: You: ""It's the kind of place where every..."
links.text: "It's the kind of place where everyone does."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""You're right, we do smoke worse th..."
links.text: "You're right, we do smoke worse than chimneys here."

links.title: You: ""I suspect I may possess supra-natu..."
links.text: "I suspect I may possess supra-natural abilities."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""No, you don't." She puts her hands..."
links.text: "No, you don't." She puts her hands into her coat pockets.

links.title: You: ""Your hands look like they belong t..."
links.text: "Your hands look like they belong to a heavy smoker."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""It's not like yours look much bett..."
links.text: "It's not like yours look much better," she says while eyeing yours.

links.title: You: "Take a look at your hands."
links.text: Take a look at your hands.

links.title: Perception (Sight): "She is right -- your hands look eve..."
links.text: She is right -- your hands look even worse than hers, with tiny cuts and gushes covering your skin like a spiderweb. Your fingertips have become an ugly shade of brown.

links.title: Visual Calculus: "These are the hands on someone who'..."
links.text: These are the hands on someone who's smoked for at least twenty years, as evidenced by the discolouration of fingers. Marks on your skin may point to past quarrels.

links.title: You: ""Alright, got it, thanks.""
links.text: "Alright, got it, thanks."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Mhmh." She returns to her book."
links.text: "Mhmh." She returns to her book.

links.title: You: "Give her a hug."
links.text: Give her a hug.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "You step in and close your arms aro..."
links.text: You step in and close your arms around this foreign body, wandering astray in touch. There's a small movement beneath your hands, as you shut your eyes. Then a tiny voice breaks out and asks:

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What is happening?""
links.text: "What is happening?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She seems to be confused. Your hand..."
links.text: She seems to be confused. Your hands are wrapped around her polyester coat. The fabric feels cold, moist from the sea nearby.

links.title: You: "Keep hugging her."
links.text: Keep hugging her.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "The situation is oddly intimate --..."
links.text: The situation is oddly intimate -- your cheek is pressed against her shoulder, her hand is trapped between your chest. Five seconds pass and their passing seems so unimaginably long. Then she coughs and says again:

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Uh... what are you doing, officer?""
links.text: "Uh... what are you doing, officer?"

links.title: Inland Empire: "Less talk, more feeling. Keep your..."
links.text: Less talk, more feeling. Keep your eyes closed, soak in the closeness. See what the feeling entails.

links.title: You: "Keep your eyes closed for a brief l..."
links.text: Keep your eyes closed for a brief longer.

links.title: Inland Empire: "The feeling continues. Warm and com..."
links.text: The feeling continues. Warm and comfy on the cold shoreline. You hear a question rising to the surface, trying to break the sensation.

links.title: You: "Let it form."
links.text: Let it form.

links.title: Inland Empire: "So tell me, how does it feel -- to..."
links.text: So tell me, how does it feel -- to be close to someone, skin to skin?

links.title: You: "It all comes together now. I was bu..."
links.text: It all comes together now. I was built to be close with other beings.

links.title: You: "It's good, but I'd prefer a man. A..."
links.text: It's good, but I'd prefer a man. A solid muscularity would support me better.

links.title: You: "Intimacy? It's a catastrophe waitin..."
links.text: Intimacy? It's a catastrophe waiting in the wings.

links.title: You: "Silence your thoughts. I don't want..."
links.text: Silence your thoughts. I don't want to answer anything.

links.title: Inland Empire: "You focus on the hug and for a mome..."
links.text: You focus on the hug and for a moment everything feels serene. You hear her heart beating -- or perhaps it's your own.

links.title: Inland Empire: "I wonder how long has it been since..."
links.text: I wonder how long has it been since you last hugged someone?

links.title: You: "Muscles, I said muscles! I want man..."
links.text: Muscles, I said muscles! I want manly-manly muscles.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Khm, officer." A coarse female voi..."
links.text: "Khm, officer." A coarse female voice pulls you out of your reverie. "What are you doing?" A swash of water hits the coast behind her figure.

links.title: Perception (Hearing): "You were eavesdropping on your subc..."
links.text: You were eavesdropping on your subconsciousness.

links.title: You: "Do I remember?"
links.text: Do I remember?

links.title: Inland Empire: "No, you don't. And it's better that..."
links.text: No, you don't. And it's better that way.

links.title: You: "What *do* I remember?"
links.text: What *do* I remember?

links.title: Inland Empire: "Nothing."
links.text: Nothing.

links.title: Inland Empire: "DON'T COME BACK HERE!"
links.text: DON'T COME BACK HERE!

links.title: You: "Open your eyes!"
links.text: Open your eyes!

links.title: You: "What the fuck was that?"
links.text: What the fuck was that?

links.title: Inland Empire: "OH MY GOD, WHY ARE YOU CALLING ME?..."
links.text: OH MY GOD, WHY ARE YOU CALLING ME? STOP CALLING ME! ARE YOU DRUNK AGAIN?

links.title: You: "PLEASE OPEN YOUR EYES!"
links.text: PLEASE OPEN YOUR EYES!

links.title: You: "Keep them closed."
links.text: Keep them closed.

links.title: Inland Empire: "I DON'T WANT TO SEE YOU. I DON'T WA..."
links.text: I DON'T WANT TO SEE YOU. I DON'T WANT TO SEE YOU EVER AGAIN! STOP CALLING ME! GET LOST FROM MY LIFE, YOU RUINED IT!

links.title: You: "But I *need* to remember."
links.text: But I *need* to remember.

links.title: You: "Well, if you say it's better..."
links.text: Well, if you say it's better...

links.title: Inland Empire: "No thoughts to come back to, no sce..."
links.text: No thoughts to come back to, no scenes to replay.. It feels calm the way deep sleep is supposed to be.

links.title: You: "No, please. I don't really want to..."
links.text: No, please. I don't really want to remember.

links.title: You: ""I had the strangest... I'm not eve..."
links.text: "I had the strangest... I'm not even sure."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""You had the strangest what?" She h..."
links.text: "You had the strangest what?" She hasn't let go of your embrace.

links.title: You: ""A strangest conversation. Somethin..."
links.text: "A strangest conversation. Something went wrong in my head."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""It's okay. We all feel out of sort..."
links.text: "It's okay. We all feel out of sorts at times." She starts patting your back. "There you go, officer."

links.title: Conceptualization: "Today the makeshift consolations: t..."
links.text: Today the makeshift consolations: the shared cigarette, the masculine jokes. Today the embrace before hurting.

links.title: You: ""It's still happening. I'm in delir..."
links.text: "It's still happening. I'm in delirium."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I'm sorry, I don't really understa..."
links.text: "I'm sorry, I don't really understand what you're talking about." She lets go of your hug.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks worried. "We c..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks worried. "We can take a break if you're feeling unwell," he says to you under his breath.

links.title: You: ""Something begged me to open my eye..."
links.text: "Something begged me to open my eyes. It was scary."

links.title: You: ""Thanks. I feel better already.""
links.text: "Thanks. I feel better already."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Good." She lets go of your hug."
links.text: "Good." She lets go of your hug.

links.title: You: ""A glitch of a sort, I think. Insid..."
links.text: "A glitch of a sort, I think. Inside my mind."

links.title: You: ""I don't want to talk about it.""
links.text: "I don't want to talk about it."

links.title: You: ""I am fighting for the working clas..."
links.text: "I am fighting for the working class."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Fighting for it how?" She hasn't l..."
links.text: "Fighting for it how?" She hasn't let go of your embrace yet.

links.title: You: ""Hug-by-hug.""
links.text: "Hug-by-hug."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Oh..." There's a strange sensation..."
links.text: "Oh..." There's a strange sensation as the woman strengthens her grip -- she's hugging you back.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I guess it's better than nothing...."
links.text: "I guess it's better than nothing. Keep fighting on, my fellow comrade." Then she breaks up the hug, her cheeks flushed.

links.title: You: ""One hug at a time.""
links.text: "One hug at a time."

links.title: You: ""A hug a day keeps the bourgeoisie..."
links.text: "A hug a day keeps the bourgeoisie away."

links.title: You: ""Hey, I hug whomever I please! I'm..."
links.text: "Hey, I hug whomever I please! I'm a hug monster."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""A hug monster? How do these two go..."
links.text: "A hug monster? How do these two go hand-in-hand?" She hasn't let go of your embrace yet.

links.title: You: ""They don't. I just forced them thi..."
links.text: "They don't. I just forced them this way. That's why I am a monster."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Right, uh..." She pats you on your..."
links.text: "Right, uh..." She pats you on your back, before gently letting go.

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Is there anything else I can help..."
links.text: "Is there anything else I can help you with?"

links.title: You: ""Well, you're not actually entitled..."
links.text: "Well, you're not actually entitled to another person's body. Hugging can be considered a rather monstrous thing to do."

links.title: You: "Let go."
links.text: Let go.

links.title: Working Class Woman: "She steps back and returns her atte..."
links.text: She steps back and returns her attention to books, pretending this hug didn't happen.

links.title: You: ""That's all for the moment. I'll le..."
links.text: "That's all for the moment. I'll let you read." [Leave.]

links.title: Working Class Woman: "The woman before you nods and retur..."
links.text: The woman before you nods and returns to her reading.

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still browsi..."

links.title: You: "[Leave.]"
links.text: [Leave.]

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: "She's still browsing books."

links.title: You: ""I'm a policeman.""
links.text: "I'm a policeman."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""I know you are.""
links.text: "I know you are."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Everyone can see that. The rectang..."
links.text: "Everyone can see that. The rectangles." He points to his sleeve.

links.title: You: ""Good then.""
links.text: "Good then."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Mhm." She reverts her attention to..."
links.text: "Mhm." She reverts her attention to the soggy books on the book stand.

links.title: You: ""Do you need the help of a policema..."
links.text: "Do you need the help of a policeman?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""What with?" She tries hard to focu..."
links.text: "What with?" She tries hard to focus on the book stand.

links.title: Reaction Speed: "What *with*? A lot of things! For e..."
links.text: What *with*? A lot of things! For example, people tend to go *missing*.

links.title: Authority: "This citizen thinks she can do with..."
links.text: This citizen thinks she can do without your assistance? Don't buy it. They all need help.

links.title: Physical Instrument: "Help her by... carrying things? Uhm..."
links.text: Help her by... carrying things? Uhm... maybe she needs a weightlifter? Maybe she needs you to *fight* her husband? No, that's not it...

links.title: You: "[Leave.]"
links.text: [Leave.]

links.title: You: "[Leave.]"
links.text: [Leave.]

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still browsi..."

links.title: You: ""Shouldn't a working class woman be..."
links.text: "Shouldn't a working class woman be working?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Not all the time. Right now I'm br..."
links.text: "Not all the time. Right now I'm browsing books." She pauses. "Even a working class woman needs something to read."

links.title: You: ""Phenomenal.""
links.text: "Phenomenal."

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""It is.""
links.text: "It is."

links.title: You: "[Leave.]"
links.text: [Leave.]

links.title: You: ""Good, good." (Nod.)"
links.text: "Good, good." (Nod.)

links.title: You: ""I'm a policeman.""
links.text: "I'm a policeman."

links.title: You: ""What are you doing?""
links.text: "What are you doing?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Looking for something to read." Sh..."
links.text: "Looking for something to read." She reverts her attention to a worn out paperback.

links.title: You: ""Have a good day." [Leave.]"
links.text: "Have a good day." [Leave.]

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""This was a tremendously useful int..."
links.text: "This was a tremendously useful interlude."

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still mumbli..."
dialogueTree.text: "Hmm-hmm-hmm..." She's still mumbling to herself, now reading another paperback.

dialogueTree.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hmm-hmm-hmm." You see a sturdy wom..."
dialogueTree.text: "Hmm-hmm-hmm." You see a sturdy woman humming to herself. She seems to be browsing books.

links.title: Perception (Hearing): ""The ship takes off like a silvery..."
links.text: "The ship takes off like a silvery mosquito... unfolding its rotor blade arms..." She mumbles reading. Then puts down the softcover.

links.title: You: ""Is that "Loos, Radio City" you're..."
links.text: "Is that "Loos, Radio City" you're reading?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Yes, a sci-fi," she says without r..."
links.text: "Yes, a sci-fi," she says without reverting her attention from the book.

links.title: You: ""Who are you?""
links.text: "Who are you?"

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Me?" She looks up briefly. "No one..."
links.text: "Me?" She looks up briefly. "No one, I'm just a working class woman."

links.title: Empathy: "She doesn't really want to be distu..."
links.text: She doesn't really want to be disturbed that much...

links.title: Logic: "If she's such a *working class* wom..."
links.text: If she's such a *working class* woman, why isn't she working?

links.title: You: ""A good one?" (Point at the book.)"
links.text: "A good one?" (Point at the book.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Yes, hello." She nods, her attenti..."
links.text: "Yes, hello." She nods, her attention fully focused on reading.

links.title: You: ""Hello." (No ceremonies. Just hello..."
links.text: "Hello." (No ceremonies. Just hello.)

links.title: Working Class Woman: ""Hello." She nods, her attention fu..."
links.text: "Hello." She nods, her attention fully focused on reading.

links.title: You: "[Leave her be.]"
links.text: [Leave her be.]
